Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program to Professor Kara L. Bren of the University of Rochester will support the development of biomolecular catalysts for the production of hydrogen fuel from water. Hydrogen is an attractive, clean fuel because it is energy dense and when burned, produces only water as a byproduct. In this project, Professor Bren will prepare and optimize inexpensive, nontoxic hydrogen evolution catalysts consisting of peptides bound to metal ions. Successful catalysts will be interfaced with light-absorbing molecules to create an artificial photosynthetic system that allows sunlight to drive hydrogen production. This award will support the training of graduate students in state-of-the art biochemical, electrochemical, and photochemical techniques. To enhance the diversity of the scientific workforce, this award also will support the participation of hearing-impaired students from the National Technical Institute for the Deaf in research seminars and summer research at the University of Rochester.

This project will develop a new class of hydrogen evolution catalysts consisting of small metallopeptides. Metallopeptides are attractive catalysts because they are easy to synthesize, soluble in water, modular, and genetically encodable. These properties facilitate the preparation, modification, and incorporation of catalysts into functional assemblies. Modifications to the catalysts will be made by altering the charge, hydrogen-donor ability, coordinating groups, and flexibility of the peptide ligands. The hydrogen evolution activity will be tested electrochemically. Variants of the catalysts will be prepared to optimize their stability, turnover frequency, and overpotential. Catalysts that perform well by these measures will be incorporated into biosynthetic assemblies for light-driven hydrogen evolution. Success in this project will provide environmentally friendly, water-soluble systems for the storage of solar energy in the form of hydrogen fuel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The development of new methods for producing hydrogen (H2) fuel from water is an area of great current interest in chemistry. This process requires a catalyst to facilitate the assembly of two aqueous protons and two electrons into hydrogen. In the project supported by this grant, we have developed a new class of catalysts for this reaction consisting of cobalt metallopeptides (see image). These simple biomolecular catalysts are capable of producing hydrogen from water near neutral pH in the presence of air. To perform this reaction, energetic electrons are provided either from an electrode (electrocatalysis) or from a photoexcited molecule (a photocatalytic system). The demonstration that these metallopeptides function in a photocatalytic system shows that they are effective for use in artificial photosynthesis, or the storing of light energy in the form of a fuel.

In addition to developing these catalysts and demonstrating their activity, this project has supported investigations of the mechanism by which they work. In particular, we found that the buffer added to the solution impacts the electrocatalytic activity, and propose that the buffer delivers the protons to the catalyst. This discovery has opened up new approaches to probing mechanism by these catalysts and enhances our understanding of reaction pathways in water more generally.

In artificial photosynthetic systems, the photoexcited electron donor provides electrons to the catalyst, and then the electron donor then must be replenished so that it can perform another cycle of hydrogen production. These electrons are typically provided by a sacrificial electron donor, such as ascorbic acid. To provide an alternative approach, we have developed a new electrode material onto which we grow biofilms of electron-donating bacteria; the electrons then can be provided to the system from the bioelectrode. These bacteria feed on organic waste, extracting electrons from waste, and then transfering electrons to the electrode. This is a new approach to providing electrons to a system for solar hydrogen production.

 

Broader Impacts:

Hydrogen (H2) is an important molecule used in a many industrial processes including the production of ammonia for fertilizers and the synthesis of liquid fuels. Hydrogen also is an energy-dense fuel that can be used for a wide range of applications. For example, hydrogen fuel cell cars are now on the market, and hydrogen filling stations are available in some localities. Hydrogen can be made through electrolysis of water or by steam-reforming natural gas. The process of making hydrogen from natural gas consumes methane, which itself is a useful fuel; this process also results in high emissions. Thus, producing hydrogen from water is attractive. However, hydrogen production from water currently is inefficient, requiring high energy input. The research supported by this grant has advanced the development of catalysts for the efficient production of hydrogen from water. The catalysts developed in this project have a number of attractive properties: they are soluble in water, they do not contain highly expensive or toxic elements, and they are modular and readily modifiable. Importantly, these catalysts are amenable to detailed study, which has yielded new insights into how catalysts handle electrons and protons in reactions in water.

This project also supported the training, in whole or in part, of five chemistry graduate students, one postdoc, and two summer students. Two of the graduate students (both women) earned PhDs and have continued on in research, as has the postdoc. One of these PhD graduates will be starting an independent faculty position in February 2018.  Two of the other graduate students are now completing their PhD work. All of the graduate students have presented their work in poster presentations or in oral presentations at conferences. The summer student on this project is a profoundly deaf student from the National Technical Institute for the Deaf in Rochester. Her experience in our lab demonstrated to her that she can contribute to a research operation, and also enlightened the graduate students about contributions to science that can be made by people with disabilities. This grant thus has supported the training of a diverse range of young people who will be part of the next generation of scientists. The P.I. also presented this work in talks to a diverse set of audiences around the U.S. and the world. These talks presented the scientific advances made and explained the importance of developing new approaches to providing energy.
